repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Financial and Legal Management
            Upgrading Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely. Following are several lessons
            drawn from the project. Provision of external training,
            equipment, and vehicles can be successful instruments in
            developing legal institutions, provided there is a
            fundamental respect for the rule of law, as demonstrated by
            the judiciary concerted actions to better serve commercial
            parties, evidenced now by the commercial trust in the legal
            recourse. Hence, it was the sense of professional duty, and
            pride that contributed to establish, and accelerate
            commercial cases, further emphasized by those basic, project
            inputs, needed to operate professionally. However, even
            under optimal professional circumstances, the absence of
            project leadership in the use of resources, hindered
            success, for the arbitrary, and secretive management, led to
            an incoherent strategy at the start of the project. In
            addition, the lack of qualified contractors, and procurement
            specialists, could have been avoided had an intensive
            assistance been in place to select appropriate contractors,
            and ensure satisfactory performance. Public sector reform,
            accompanied by adequate compensation is vital to ensure the
            institutional benefits of staff training, for in the absence
            of civil service pay reform, training becomes an incentive
            to work in the public sector, but only on a transitory basis.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Financial and Legal Management
            Upgrading Project (FILMUP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of this project are to
            improve the flow of government business, improve the
            implementation of development programs, and facilitate
            reform, by removing identified obstacles through capacity
            building and institutional development in the areas of
            accounting and auditing, public sector procurement, legal
            drafting, the administration of justice, and the provision
            of business information.  The project is divided into two
            main parts:  financial management upgrading, comprising
            improvements to accounting and procurement services; legal
            management upgrading, which consists of improvements to
            legal services. The project will provide assistance for:
            (a) financial management improvement through: (i)
            accountancy development and training the main professional
            accountancy organization and three major accountancy
            training institutions; and (ii) procurement improvement by
            providing training, equipment, and technical assistance to
            the Zambia National Tender Board; (b) legal management
            upgrading through the provision of training, equipment,
            minor building rehabilitation works, and essential
            publications for the Ministry of Legal Affairs and its major
            agencies including the Judiciary, the Industrial Relations
            Court and the Law Practice Institute as well as for the
            Registrar of Companies and legal services of a few key
            ministries; (c) project coordination and management to pay
            for the office costs and salaries of two project
            coordinators:  one for the financial management component,
            who will also serve as the project accountant, and the other
            for the legal management component, the costs of a
            procurement specialist, a supervising architect, the costs
            of the project launch workshop, the independent audit of
            project accounts, studies and computers software, and the
            incremental operating costs of project institutions.
